awd_titl_txt: Laboratory Technician Support:  University of Connecticut Helium Geothermochronology Laboratory
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will fund a laboratory technician in the Helium Geothermochronology Laboratory (HGL) at the University of Connecticut. The HGL supports research in low-temperature (U-Th)/He thermochronology of a wide range of minerals, including apatite, zircon, titanite, and monazite. This award will enable the broader Earth science community to gain access to the HGL facility and will support visitor training and applications and development in geothermochronology. This laboratory technician support award will also promote science in society by providing student training and education in a laboratory setting, enhancing the research program of an early career geoscientist, and promoting engagement of local Mansfield, CT community through science outreach activities centering on deep time and dating methods in the tectonics, geochemistry, sedimentology, paleoclimatology, and geoarchaeology. 

Research in the HGL focuses on resolving the timing and mechanisms of exhumation during mountain building, with specific concentration on sediment provenance analysis using detrital multi-mineral (U-Th)/He geothermochronology. This award will support HGL efforts to develop improved methodology on a wider suite of detrital minerals, such as titanite, monazite, and apatite, among others. The laboratory technician will be expected to (1) supervise on-campus and visiting students and researchers, (2) contribute to ongoing research and methodological development of (U-Th)/He geothermochronology at UConn, (3) conduct routine laboratory duties and instrument maintenance, (4) provide fee-for-service analytical support for scientific and applied research projects, and (5) participate in community outreach activities to promote public interest and knowledge in deep-time, geochronology, and Earth processes.

por.por_cntn:
The laboratory technician award enabled us to make our instrumentation and expertise in the Basin Analysis and Thermochronology Laboratory (BAHTL) in the Department of Earth Sciences at the University of Connecticut broadly accessible to students and researchers. Thermochronology, a subset of geochemistry, is used to evaluate mineral cooling as rocks move upward from the deep Earth towards the Earth’s surface. This information provides an important metric across a range of disciplines, including paleoclimate studies, tectonic reconstructions, geohazards, critical minerals, energy resources, and geoarchaeology. Sample preparation and data acquisition are specialized and time-consuming.

Over the six years of the project, we supported 58 students and faculty researchers hosted through BAHTL serviced projects and 24 campus visits. Laboratory visitors learned mineral identification and sample preparation, measurement of helium isotopes, and data integration and interpretation. We supported researchers from across a range of institution types, spanning four-year colleges, B.S./B.A. only granting institutions, state/federal agencies, and international universities. Thus far, data generated in the BAHTL has been disseminated through nine peer-reviewed journal publications spanning high-impact science journals, including Science and the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, and top disciplinary journals such Earth and Planetary Science Letters, and Geophysical Research Letters, and 23 scientific abstracts in regional, national, and international conferences. 

The NSF supported BAHTL activities had positive broader impacts on society by providing technical training and professional mentoring to the next generation of geochronologists. We supported 23 early-career researchers, 24 graduate students, and three undergraduate students. To date, BAHTL supported datasets have been the foundation of 8 student theses. We also contributed to capacity building by coordinating meetings and discussion with other geochronology laboratories to build a national geochronology consortium. Throughout the duration of the award, our activities have focused on fostering and supporting a diverse geoscience community. We hosted visitors from 13 different U.S. states and two countries in addition to the U.S. Nearly half of our supported projects were led by researchers and students who identify as women. Within the local community, we have hosted open-house lab tours for high school students and have provided outreach materials in geochronology and Earth Science for the University of Connecticut's Earth Science Day annual event.


Last Modified: 09/27/2024
Modified by: Julie C Fosdick
